awd_titl_txt: CNS Core: Small: Secured Spectrum Allocation and Patrolling in Shared Spectrum Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The RF spectrum is a natural resource in great demand and a tremendous economic driver. Shared spectrum systems, which facilitate spectrum allocation to unlicensed users without harming the licensed users, offer great promise in optimizing spectrum utility. However, spectrum management in such systems is challenging mainly due to the lack of knowledge of signal propagation characteristics in the geographic areas. Thus, spectrum allocation in such systems is either done very conservatively or is based on imperfect models. Efficient spectrum utilization also depends on the ability to guard against unauthorized usage attacks; however, the current techniques are limited. The goal of this project is to develop effective spectrum management techniques by leveraging a large number of spectrum sensors in a crowdsensed architecture. In general, improved spectrum efficiency could impact many diverse fields such as IoT, education, cyber-physical systems security, healthcare, media and entertainment, which have tremendous future spectrum needs and innovation is perhaps halted due to lack of enough bandwidth. Thus, improved spectrum utilization via efficient allocation and patrolling is bound to yield significant economic benefits. This project is expected to provide technology inputs for industry and inform regulators about best practices and tradeoffs.

This project will develop efficient and secured techniques for spectrum allocation and patrolling, for a shared spectrum system, by leveraging a large number of crowdsourced spectrum sensors. The project’s focus will be on using deep-learning techniques to obviate the need to assume a propagation model. The project has the following research themes: 1. Spectrum Allocation. The project will develop efficient supervised learning techniques to learn the spectrum allocation function, in general settings. 2. Privacy Preserving Spectrum Management Protocols. To maximize participation in a crowdsourced sensing model, it is imperative to preserve privacy of the entities involved in the spectrum management. Thus, the project will develop efficient cryptographic protocols that provide privacy to all system entities. 3. Spectrum Patrolling. Preventing unauthorized access of the shared spectrum is key to improved spectrum utilization. Thus, the project will develop efficient techniques to protect the spectrum from unauthorized access, by developing effective deep learning approaches to localize intruders. 4. Evaluation. The project will evaluate the overall system, over three simulation platforms including: (i) small indoor and outdoor testbeds, and (ii) a simulation platform that will use channel-state data gathered by drones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
RF spectrum is a natural resource with great demand and a tremendous economic driver.  Shared spectrum systems, which facilitate spectrum allocation to unlicensed users without harming the licensed users,  offer great promise in optimizing spectrum utility, but their management is challenging.  A significant shortcoming of current spectrum management architectures and methods is that spectrum allocation is either done very conservatively to ensure correctness, or is based on imperfect  propagation models and/or  spectrum sensing with poor spatial granularity. Efficient spectrum utilization in shared spectrum systems also depends on their ability to guard against unauthorized usage attacks, e.g., due to malware on SDR devices, selfish users making unauthorized transmissions or causing spectrum jamming attacks. However, the current techniques to protect the spectrum against unauthorized usage and attacks are ineffective and limited; e.g., they are largely focused on single intruders. To address the above challenges, the goal of this project was to develop techniques to maximize spectrum utilization in shared spectrum systems. In particular, the project aimed  to leverage a large number of crowdsourced spectrum sensors in a crowdsourced architecture and develop efficient and secured techniques for spectrum allocation and patrolling/protection.

In the above context, the proposal had the following outcomes over the life of the project:

--- Learning-Based Efficient Spectrum Allocation. The project developed efficient machine learning techniques to learn the spectrum allocation function, when the information about the primary transmitters may be unavailable. We designed techniques for various settings in this context, and via extensive large-scale simulation and a small testbed, we demonstrated the effectiveness of our developed techniques.

-- Privacy-Preserving Spectrum Management Protocols. To maximize participation in a crowdsourced sensing model, it is imperative to preserve privacy of private information of the entities involved in the spectrum management. Thus, we  developed efficient secured spectrum-management protocols that provide maximum possible privacy to all system entities, under semi-honest as well as malicious settings.

--- Learning-Based Spectrum Patrolling.  Preventing unauthorized access of the shared spectrum is key to improved spectrum utilization. Thus, the project developed efficient techniques to protect the spectrum from unauthorized access; in particular, we developed  efficient  deep-learning approaches to localize multiple intruders under general shared spectrum settings. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach via extensive large-scale simulations and a small testbed, and show that our approach outperforms the previous approaches significantly (by 50% or more) in accuracy and incurs an order of magnitude less latency.

– Transmitter Localization using a Quantum Sensor Network. A quantum sensor (QS) can measure various physical phenomena with extreme sensitivity. We developed techniques for localization of a shared-spectrum intruder (i.e., an unauthorized transmitter in a shared spectrum) using a network of quantum sensors. Our approaches pose the localization problem as a well-studied quantum state discrimination (QSD) problem, and use a two-level localization approach to first localize the transmitter at a coarser granularity first and then at a finer granularity in the second level. 

 

Broader Impact. In general, improved spectrum efficiency could impact many diverse fields such as IoT, education, cyber-physical systems security, healthcare, media and entertainment, which have tremendous future spectrum needs and innovation is perhaps halted due to lack of enough bandwidth.  Thus, improved spectrum utilization via efficient allocation and patrolling is bound to bring in indirect economic benefits. The techniques developed in the project provide technology inputs and effective solutions for industry and inform regulators about tradeoffs.
